The series was directed by [[Tetsurō Araki]] and written by [[Ichirō Ōkouchi]],{{cite web|title=Attack on Titan Team, Code Geass Writer Make Kōtetsujō no Kabaneri Anime|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-11-27/attack-on-titan-team-code-geass-writer-make-kotetsujo-no-kabaneri-anime/.81502|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=November 27, 2014}} with music by [[Hiroyuki Sawano]] and original character designs by [[Haruhiko Mikimoto]]. The series premiered on [[Fuji Television|Fuji TV]]'s [[Noitamina]] block on April 8, 2016 and ended on June 30, 2016 with a total of 12 episodes.{{cite web|url=http://kabaneri.com/package/sp/03/|title=Blu-ray&DVD 「甲鉄城のカバネリ」公式サイト|accessdate=May 20, 2016|language=Japanese}} A prologue for the anime premiered for a week in theaters across Japan starting March 18, 2016.{{cite web|title=Attack on Titan Team's Kōtetsujō no Kabaneri Anime Trailers Reveal Premise, April Premiere|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2015-12-17/attack-on-titan-team-kotetsujo-no-kabaneri-anime-trailers-reveal-premise-april-premiere/.96632|date=December 17, 2015|website=Anime News Network|accessdate=January 25, 2016}}{{cite web|last=Chapman|first=Paul|title=VIDEO: It's Trains vs. Zombies in "Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress" Trailer|url=https://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2015/12/17/video-its-trains-vs-zombies-in-kabaneri-of-the-iron-fortress-trailer|date=December 18, 2015|website=[[Crunchyroll]]|accessdate=January 25, 2016}} [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] streamed the series on their [[Amazon Video|Amazon Prime Instant Video]] service.{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-03-14/amazon-prime-to-stream-kabaneri-of-the-iron-fortress-anime-from-attack-on-titan-team/.99749|title=Amazon Prime to Stream Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress Anime From Attack on Titan Team|date=March 14, 2016|website=Anime News Network|accessdate=March 14, 2016}} Two compilation films premiered in Japanese theaters on December 31, 2016, and January 7, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-06-30/kabaneri-of-the-iron-fortress-gets-theatrical-compilation-editions/.103816|title=Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress Gets Theatrical Compilation Editions|date=June 30, 2016|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=June 30, 2016}} [[Crunchyroll]] and [[Funimation]] co-released the anime on Blu-ray and DVD in the United States; [[Crunchyroll]] also acquired the merchandise rights.{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-07-01/crunchyroll-to-dub-release-anime-on-bd-dvd/.103876|title=Crunchyroll to Dub Release Anime on BD/DVD|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date= July 1, 2016|accessdate= July 1, 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/09/08/crunchyroll-and-funimation-partner-to-expand-access-to-anime|title=Crunchyroll and Funimation Partner to Expand access to Anime|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=September 8, 2016|accessdate=September 8, 2016}} A [[mobile game]] developed by TriFort, Inc. and published by [[DMM.com|DMM Games]] titled {{nihongo|''Kōtetsujō no Kabaneri -Ran- Hajimaru Michiato''|甲鉄城のカバネリ -乱-||lit. "Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress -Revolt- Beginning Tracks"}} is scheduled for release in December 2018 on [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[iOS]], featuring an animated opening sequence by Wit Studio.{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-03-02/kabaneri-of-the-iron-fortress-browser-smartphone-game-reveals-visual-title/.128485|title=Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress Browser/Smartphone Game Reveals Visual, Title|date=March 2, 2018|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=March 8, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://otakumode.com/news/5bdaba9239f37eb827692ef2/Kabaneri-of-the-Iron-Fortress-Game-Set-to-Release-in-Dec-2018!|title=Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress Game Set to Release in Dec. 2018!|date=November 2, 2018|website=Tokyo Otaku Mode|accessdate=November 9, 2018}} An anime theatrical film that is set six months after the anime series, titled {{nihongo|''Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress: The Battle of Unato''|甲鉄城のカバネリ 〜海門決戦〜|Kōtetsujō no Kabaneri: Unato Kessen}}, is scheduled to premiere in Q2 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-03-08/kabaneri-of-the-iron-fortress-unato-kessen-sequel-anime-film-revealed/.128711|title=Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress: Unato Kessen Sequel Anime Film Revealed|date=March 8, 2018|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=March 8, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2018-10-20/kabaneri-of-the-iron-fortress-the-battle-of-unato-sequel-anime-film-reveals-teaser-video-visual/.138407|title=Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress: The Battle of Unato Sequel Anime Film Reveals Teaser Video, Visual|date=October 20, 2018|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=November 9, 2018}} ==Plot== A mysterious virus appears during the [[industrial revolution]] that transforms infected humans into {{nihongo|''Kabane''|カバネ||"corpses"}} and rapidly spreads. ''Kabane'' are aggressive, [[undead]] creatures that cannot be defeated unless the glowing heart, which is protected by a layer of lead, is pierced, or an important body part is completely severed (such as the head). Unfortunately, most melee weapons and the steam-pressure guns used by the {{nihongo|''[[samurai|bushi]]''|武士||"soldiers"}} are not very effective against them. On the island country {{nihongo|[[Japan|Hinomoto]]|日ノ本}}, people have built fortress-like "stations" to shelter themselves from these creatures. People access the stations and transport wares between them with the help of {{nihongo|fortified steam locomotives|駿城|hayajirō}}. One day, a ''hayajirō'' hijacked by the ''Kabane'' crashes into Aragane Station and they overrun the city. A young engineer called Ikoma uses the opportunity to test with success his anti-''Kabane'' weapon, the {{nihongo|"piercing gun"|ツラヌキ筒|tsuranuki zutsu}}, but is infected in the process, although he manages to resist the virus and become a {{nihongo|''Kabaneri''|カバネリ}}, a human-''Kabane'' hybrid. Assisted by {{nihongo|Mūmei|無名||"Nameless"}}, another ''Kabaneri'' who appears to help them, Ikoma and the other survivors of the station board a ''hayajirō'' named {{nihongo|''Kōtetsujō''|甲鉄城||"Iron Fortress"}} and depart to seek shelter elsewhere, fighting the hordes of ''Kabane'' along the way. ==Characters== ;{{nihongo|Ikoma|生駒}} : {{voiced by|[[Tasuku Hatanaka]]|[[Robbie Daymond]]}}{{cite web|title=Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress English Dub Stars Robbie Daymond, Janice Kawaye|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-11-03/kabaneri-of-the-iron-fortress-english-dub-stars-robbie-daymond-janice-kawaye/.123582|publisher=Anime News Network|date=November 3, 2017|accessdate=November 3, 2017}} :A young man who makes a living as a steamsmith at Aragane Station. He and his good friend Takumi developed a [[Captive bolt pistol|bolt gun-like]] weapon called a ''piercing gun'' in order to defeat the Kabane. When Aragane Station is invaded by Kabane, Ikoma is able to successfully test his piercing gun but is bitten by a Kabane in the process. He is able to prevent the virus from reaching his brain by blocking his carotid arteries, transforming him into a Kabaneri. ;{{nihongo|Mumei|無名}} : {{voiced by|[[Sayaka Senbongi]]|[[Janice Kawaye]]}} :A mysterious and anonymoushttp://www.kanjijapanese.com/en/dictionary-japanese-english/mumei girl who boards the hayajiro ''Kotetsujo'' and appears at Aragane Station. She is revealed to be a Kabaneri as well as a very strong and agile fighter, capable of killing dozens of Kabane with ease. She became a Kabaneri through a surgical operation as the result of her brainwashing by Biba, making her believe unless she became stronger, she would also end up like her mother. Constant fighting can leave her sleepy and like Ikoma, she requires blood to stop herself from attacking other people. Her birth name is {{nihongo|Hozumi|穂積}} and she was named Mumei by Biba when he "saved" her as a child. ;{{nihongo|Ayame Yomogawa|四方川 菖蒲|Yomogawa Ayame}}{{cite web|url=http://news.mynavi.jp/news/2015/12/18/011/|title=ノイタミナ『甲鉄城のカバネリ』、来年4月放送! キービジュアル&PVを公開 _ マイナビニュース|accessdate=June 7, 2016|language=Japanese}} : {{voiced by|[[Maaya Uchida]]|[[Veronica Taylor]]}}{{cite web|title=Funimonster on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/FUNimation/status/924387877349482497|website=Twitter|accessdate=October 29, 2017|date=October 29, 2017}} :The eldest daughter of the Yomogawa family, which governs Aragane Station. After her father is infected, she becomes the leader of the Aragane survivors. Despite her noble status, she's reasonable and understanding, even offering her blood to the Kabaneri. She is also an expert Archer using a steam powered bow. Ayame seems to have feelings for Kurusu, her bodyguard who is around her age. ;{{nihongo|Kurusu|来栖}} :{{voiced by|[[Toshiki Masuda]]|[[Jamieson Price]]}}{{cite web|title=Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress Anime's English Dub Adds 4 More Cast Members|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-11-03/kabaneri-of-the-iron-fortress-anime-english-dub-adds-4-more-cast-members/.123576|website=Anime News Network|accessdate=November 3, 2017|date=November 3, 2017}} :A young [[Samurai|Bushi]] who serves the Yomogawa family as Ayame's personal bodyguard. Among Bushi his skill with a sword is considerable. He is usually somber and honest, and he maintains his honor as a Bushi. Despite initially resenting Ikoma, he eventually recognizes the Kabaneri's usefulness and also starts to respect him. He is later given a reinforced katana that can pierce a Kabane's heart with ease. As a side note, Kurusu seems to have feelings for Lady Ayame. ;{{nihongo|Takumi|逞生}} : {{voiced by|[[Yūki Kaji]]|[[Benjamin Diskin|Ben Diskin]]}} :Ikoma's best friend and fellow steam smith, who helped him develop his piercing gun. He dies, shot by Biba, after sacrificing his life for Ikoma. ;{{nihongo|Kajika|鰍}} : {{voiced by|[[Kanae Oki]]|[[Colleen Villard|Colleen O'Shaughnessey]]}} :Ikoma and Takumi's friend and fellow steam smith. A friendly and warm-hearted girl takes care of the children that lost their families to the Kabane. ;{{nihongo|Yukina|侑那}} : {{voiced by|[[Mariya Ise]]|Abby Trott}} :A crew member of the ''Kotetsujo''. A stoic and taciturn girl who, despite being only an apprentice, becomes the ''Kotetsujo'''s engineer and driver out of necessity. ;{{nihongo|Sukari|巣刈}} : {{voiced by|[[Ryōta Ōsaka]]|[[Tom Gibis]]}} :A steam smith who lives at Aragane Station. Despite his aloof personality, he's a good mechanic and a decent fighter. ;{{nihongo|Kibito|吉備土}} :{{voiced by|Kensuke Satou|[[Kyle Hebert]]}} :A Bushi who serves the Yomogawa family. Unlike other Bushis, he's reasonable and even friendly to the Kabaneri. He and his fellow Bushi are later given reinforced bullets that can penetrate the Kabane more easily. ;{{nihongo|Suzuki|鈴木}} :{{voiced by|Maxwell Powers|Elijah Ungvary}} :The train's chief mechanic who has hair like a 17th-century wig and speaks with English phrases. Also served as narrator for each episodes' preview. ;{{nihongo|Biba Amatori|天鳥 美馬|Amatori Biba}} :{{voiced by|[[Mamoru Miyano]]|[[Roger Craig Smith]]}} :The Leader of the {{nihongo|Hunters|狩方衆|Karikatashū}} and the eldest son of the ''[[shōgun]]''. Charismatic, ruthless and manipulative, he inducted Mumei in his philosophy of strength superiority, where the weak don't deserve to live and should not even have the will to. He greatly resents his father for abandoning him and the 400,000 men he sent to fight on the front lines by essentially starving them of supplies. This made him develop his philosophy, making his purpose from that point to kill his father and show him how weak his fear made him. To do that he intends to destroy the Kongokaku (the ''shōgun''{{'}}s stronghold) using artificially created Kabaneri, and the blue blood he developed, making artificial hybrid colonies when injected with huge destructive power. ;{{nihongo|Horobi|滅火}} : {{voiced by|[[Aya Endō]]|[[Cissy Jones]]}} :A Kabaneri member of the Hunters. She is turned into a {{nihongo|Black Fog|黒煙|Kuro Keburi}} by Biba in order to destroy the Iwato Station, only for the virus to go out of control and mutate her even more. She only stops at the sight of Biba at which point he callously murders her. ;{{nihongo|Uryuu|瓜生}} : {{voiced by|[[Kaito Ishikawa]]|Chris Niosi}}https://twitter.com/Kirbopher/status/953026412151123968 :The Captain of the Hunters, who serves under Biba Amatori. ==Anime== {|class="wikitable" style="width:98%; margin:auto; background:#FFF; table-layout:fixed;" |- style="border-bottom: 3px solid #AA1527;" ! style="width:3em;" | No. ! However, Ikoma is suspicious of Biba's past and whether he is really a hero, or something else. |Aux4 = {{cite web|url=http://kabaneri.com/story/07.html|script-title=ja:第七話 「天に願う」|trans-title=Episode 7: "Begging the Heavens"|website=kabaneri.com|accessdate=October 6, 2016|language=Japanese}} }} {{Japanese episode list |EpisodeNumber = 8 |EnglishTitle = The Silent Hunter |KanjiTitle = 黙す狩人 |RomajiTitle = Mokusu Karibito |DirectedBy = Hiroyuki Tanaka

Kunihiro Mori |WrittenBy = Ichirō Ōkouchi |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|6|2}} |LineColor = AA1527 |ShortSummary = Biba Amatori is introduced to Ayame, and reveals that he is Mumei's 'older brother' in name only and has been disowned by the ''shōgun''. The Kabane attack Shitori Station and Biba takes his Hunter squad and destroys them all, and kills a re-emerged Enoku, who he accuses of betrayal. He then offers to accompany Ayane's ''Kōtetsujō'' to Kongokaku and she accepts. Ikoma suspects that Biba turned Mumei into a Kabaneri and gave her the name Mumei for his own purposes. Biba asks Mumei to get the ''Kōtetsujō'' master key for him, but she is tricked and given the wrong key. Ikoma discovers that Biba is transporting Kabane on his train, but Biba uses Mumei to prevent him from entering the carriage. Ikoma is convinced that Biba is not a hero. |Aux4 = {{cite web|url=http://kabaneri.com/story/08.html|script-title=ja:第八話 「黙す狩人」|trans-title=Episode 8: "The Silent Hunter"|website=kabaneri.com|accessdate=October 6, 2016|language=Japanese}} }} {{Japanese episode list |EpisodeNumber = 9 |EnglishTitle = Fang of Ruin |KanjiTitle = 滅びの牙 |RomajiTitle = Horobi no Kiba |DirectedBy = Hironobu Aoyagi
Hiroyuki Tanaka
Tetsuaki Watanabe |WrittenBy = Ichirō Ōkouchi |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|6|9}} |LineColor = AA1527 |ShortSummary = The ''Kokujou'' with the Hunters is refused entry to Iwato Station, the last before Kongokaku, by the ''shōgun''{{'}}s samurai. Ayame decides to part company with the Hunters and asks Ikoma to get Mumei. Lord Maeda, leader of the fortress agrees to a meeting with Biba on the condition that only women and children accompany him. During the meeting, Mumei leaves the meeting saying that she needs to go to the toilet and lowers the Iwato Station's drawbridge to let Biba's Kabane into the station. Biba then kills Lord Maeda. When Mumei sees the Kabane attack the station she is horrified by the consequences of her actions. Meanwhile Biba's men take Ayame hostage and kill the ''shōgun''{{'}}s samurai for what Biba says is retribution for the shogunate's cowardice for the past 10 years. He believes that only the strong should survive. Biba injects his Kabaneri Horobi with a serum so that she can become the heart of another Black Fog beast, gathering all the Kabane into a single colony, a Nue. The Nue is defeated, but Horobi survives and continues to fight. When she reaches Biba, he kills her since she has served her purpose. In the aftermath, Biba and his men control a devastated Iwato Station. Mumei then realizes that everything Biba had told her was a lie. |Aux4 = {{cite web|url=http://kabaneri.com/story/09.html|script-title=ja:第九話 「滅びの牙」|trans-title=Episode 9: "Fang of Ruin"|website=kabaneri.com|accessdate=October 6, 2016|language=Japanese}} }} {{Japanese episode list |EpisodeNumber = 10 |EnglishTitle = The Attacking Weak |KanjiTitle = 攻め上ぐ弱者 |RomajiTitle = Semeagu Jakusha |DirectedBy = Hiroyuki Tanaka
Tokiyoshi Sasaki
Yasuhiro Akamatsu |WrittenBy = Hiroshi Seko |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|6|16}} |LineColor = AA1527 |ShortSummary = Biba and his troops are now in control of the hayajiro and its passengers, using their blood to feed his Kabane. Biba offers a deal to Ayame that if she can open the gates to Kongokaku, and arrange a meeting with his father, he will guarantee the safety of her people. He tells her of the time when his father sent him with 400,000 troops to Kyushu to fight the Kabane, but when replacement supplies failed to arrive they were overrun and wiped out, for which he blames his father. Meanwhile Ikoma hatches a daring plan with some of the passengers to retake control of the hayajiro. Biba offers Mumei a chance to join his troops but she refuses and is forced to take captive vaccine and sedated. Ikoma's group starts their attack to take control of the ''Kōtetsujō'', but Biba had anticipated a counter-attack and confronts Ikoma, killing Takumi who sacrifices himself to save Ikoma. Biba then calls on Mumei to kill Ikoma. She obeys his order due to Biba's captive vaccine, stabbing Ikoma who falls from the hayajiro into a coast far below. |Aux4 = {{cite web|url=http://kabaneri.com/story/10.html|script-title=ja:第十話 「攻め上ぐ弱者」|trans-title=Episode 10: "The Attacking Weak"|website=kabaneri.com|accessdate=October 6, 2016|language=Japanese}} }} {{Japanese episode list |EpisodeNumber = 11 |EnglishTitle = Burning Life |KanjiTitle = 燃える命 |RomajiTitle = Moeru Inochi |DirectedBy = Hiroyuki Tanaka
Hitomi Ezoe
Kunihiro Mori |WrittenBy = Ichirō Ōkouchi |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|6|23}} |LineColor = AA1527 |ShortSummary = Ikoma is still alive, washed up on the shore and is found by Kurusu (who went missing in the previous attack). Biba injects Mumei with the same liquid that he used on Horobi to turn her into a Nue. The ''Kōtetsujō'' arrives at Kongokaku and announces that they have captured the men who destroyed Iwato Station so they are allowed entry. Ayame pretends to have Biba prisoner because her crew are being held hostage, and they are taken to meet the ''shōgun''. Biba tricks the ''shōgun'' into holding a sword tainted with the Kabane virus which turns him into a Kabane. Biba then kills him and announces to everyone that Kabane are among them, which creates a panic and people start killing each other out of fear. The Karikatashu take the ''Kōtetsujō'' into the city and release the Kabane, while Ayame escapes with the help of her uncle. Kurusu has one of Biba's scientists prisoner with knowledge about the Kabane virus. He says that Mumei can be saved once she becomes a Nue by injecting white plasma into her heart. Ikoma insists on being injected by black plasma to give him additional strength, although it will accelerate the Kabane virus and shorten his life. Mumei begins her transformation into a Nue to fulfill Biba's dream of destruction. |Aux4 = {{cite web|url=http://kabaneri.com/story/11.html|script-title=ja:第十一話 「燃える命」|trans-title=Episode 11: "Burning Life"|website=kabaneri.com|accessdate=October 6, 2016|language=Japanese}} }} {{Japanese episode list |EpisodeNumber = 12 |EnglishTitle = Iron Fortress |KanjiTitle = 甲鉄城 |RomajiTitle = Kōtetsujō |DirectedBy = Hironobu Aoyagi
Hiroyuki Tanaka
[[Takayuki Hirao]]
Tetsurō Araki |WrittenBy = Ichirō Ōkouchi |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2016|6|30}} |LineColor = AA1527 |ShortSummary = Ikoma and Kurusu enter Kongokaku, drawing the Kabane towards them. Ayame appeals to the humans to stop attacking each other in fear, and entreats them to leave Kongokaku with her people in the ''Kōtetsujō''. With Kurusu's help, Ikoma is able to reach the Mumei Nue. He destroys the hayajiro ''Kokujou'' in the process when the Hunters try to drive it into him with his additional powers since taking the black serum. Mumei seems to be unaware of what she's become, recalling memories from the past and imagining herself surrounded by butterflies. Ikoma reaches the Mumei Nue, but is intercepted by Biba who is revealed as a Kabaneri. Biba stabs Ikoma with his sword, but this does not kill him, and as he is about to try again, Ikoma recovers and blasts him with his bolt gun. Mumei appears to understand that Ikoma is near, and she allows him to inject her with the white serum, destroying the Nue and returning her to her previous form. Ayame and her people leave the smouldering city of Kongokaku in the hayajiro ''Kōtetsujō'' with Kurusu, Mumei and injured Ikoma are on board. Ikoma starts to recover thanks to a serum secretly given by Biba and the effects of the black serum seem to diminish. As an afterthought, Mumei hands him back his green stone. |Aux4 = {{cite web|url=http://kabaneri.com/story/12.html|script-title=ja:第十二話 「甲鉄城」|trans-title=Episode 12: "Iron Fortress"|website=kabaneri.com|accessdate=October 6, 2016|language=Japanese}} }} |} ==Music== {{Infobox album | name = Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress Original Soundtrack | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Hiroyuki Sawano]] | cover = | alt = | released = May 18, 2016 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Soundtrack]] | length = {{Duration|h=1|m=17|s=45}} | label = [[Aniplex]] | producer = {{Hlist|[[Hiroyuki Sawano]]|Yasushi Horiguchi (co-producer)}} | chronology = [[Hiroyuki Sawano]] soundtrack albums | prev_title = Seraph of the End: Battle in Nagoya Original Soundtrack | prev_year = 2016 | next_title = [[Thunderbolt Fantasy#Soundtrack|Thunderbolt Fantasy Touriken Yuuki: Original Soundtrack]] | next_year = 2016 | misc = {{Singles | name = Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress: Original Soundtrack | type = soundtrack | single1 = KABANERIOFTHEIRONFORTRESS | single1date = October 8, 2016 | single2 = Warcry | single2date = October 8, 2016 }} }} The soundtrack was composed by [[Hiroyuki Sawano]] and was released by [[Aniplex]] on May 18, 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://vgmdb.net/album/57667|title=SVWC-70149 {{!}} KABANERI OF THE IRON FORTRESS ORIGINAL SOUNDTRACK - VGMdb|website=vgmdb.net|access-date=2016-11-19}} The opening theme is "Kabaneri of the Iron Fortress" by [[Egoist (band)|Egoist]] and the ending theme is "ninelie" by [[Aimer]] with [[Egoist (band)|chelly]]. {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Kamehameha'' statues}} [[File:Kamehameha I full 5110.png|thumb|right|''Kamehameha'' Statue that stands today in front of Ali{{okina}}iolani Hale]]{{Ref-improve|date=May 2018}} Several '''''Kamehameha'' Statues''' honor the [[Kamehameha I|monarch]] who founded the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.aloha-hawaii.com/tours/kamehameha+statue/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-07-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224161423/http://www.aloha-hawaii.com/tours/kamehameha+statue/ |archive-date=2010-12-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Original work== {{Main|Kamehameha statue (original cast)}} The pictured statue stands prominently in front of [[Aliiolani Hale|Ali{{okina}}iolani Hale]] in [[Honolulu, Hawaii]]. The statue had its origins in 1878 when [[Walter M. Gibson]], a member of the Hawaiian government at the time, wanted to commemorate the 100-year arrival of [[Captain Cook]] to the Hawaiian Islands. The legislature appropriated $10,000 for the project and made Gibson the director of the project, which originally included native Hawaiians but they soon were off the project and Gibson ran the project by himself. Gibson contacted [[Thomas R. Gould]], a Boston sculptor living abroad in [[Florence]], [[Italy]] to create the statue.
===Features=== Even though photographs of Polynesians had been sent to him so that Gould could make an appropriate likeness, he seemed to ignore them. A Roman nose and more European features were adopted. This is most likely due to the fact that Gould was in Italy studying Roman sculpture. The stance of a Roman general with gesturing hand, spear, and cape are also Roman appropriations. The belt or sash on the statue's waist is a symbolic rendering of the [[Sash of Liloa|Sacred Sash of Liloa]]. In 1880, the initial sculpture was sent to [[Paris]], France, to be cast in [[bronze]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gohawaii.about.com/od/oahusights/ss/honolulu_walk_a_4.htm|title=Let's Take a Walk Around Historic Honolulu|work=TripSavvy|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref>
However, historians have noted that from the photographs that were sent to Gould, certain features of the statues were influenced by Hawaiian brothers [[John Timoteo Baker]] and [[Robert Hoapili Baker]]. Two photographs of the former survive, one in its original form and another in the form composite with the bare legs of a Hawaiian fisherman.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Adler|first=Jacob|title=Kamehameha Statue|journal=The Hawaiian Journal of History|location=Honolulu|publisher=Hawaiian Historical Society|volume=3|year=1969|hdl=10524/570|oclc=60626541|pages=203–212}}; {{cite journal|last=Rose|first=Roger G.|title=Woodcarver F. N. Otremba and the Kamehameha Statue|journal=The Hawaiian Journal of History|location=Honolulu|publisher=Hawaiian Historical Society|volume=22|year=1988|hdl=10524/505|oclc=60626541|pages=131–146}}; {{cite journal|last=Charlot|first=Jean|title=Letter To Jacob Adler On The Statue Of Kamehameha By Thomas R. Gould|date=July 1969|publisher=Jean Charlot Foundation|location=|url=http://www.jeancharlot.org/writings/english/1969%20JACOB%20ADLER.pdf}}; {{cite magazine|last=Dekneef|first=Matthew|title=Two Hawaiian Brothers Who Modeled For The Iconic Kamehameha Statue|magazine=Hawaiʻi Magazine|location=Honolulu|date=June 10, 2016|volume=|issue=|page=|url=http://www.hawaiimagazine.com/content/these-are-two-hawaiian-brothers-who-modeled-iconic-kamehameha-statue|accessdate=November 15, 2016}}</ref>
During this time, David [[Kalākaua]] became king and was completing [[ʻIolani Palace]] which was his tribute to King [[Kamehameha I]] and to be the destination of the statue. The statue was too late for the 100th anniversary, but in 1883, the statue was placed aboard a ship and headed for Hawaii. Near the [[Falkland Islands]] the ship wrecked and the statue was thought lost. However, the Hawaiians had insured the statue for $12,000 and a second casting was quickly made.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aoc.gov/cc/art/nsh/kamehameha.cfm|title=Kamehameha I|work=Architect of the Capitol {{!}} United States Capitol|access-date=2018-05-15|language=en}}</ref>
===Replicas=== {{See also|Kamehameha I (Gould)}} [[File:Kamehameha statue Kohala.jpg|thumb|The first casting of the Gould statue, now at [[Kapaau, Hawaii|Kapa{{okina}}au]], North [[Kohala, Hawaii|Kohala]] ]] Before the second statue could be sent, the original was recovered by some Falkland Islanders. They sold it to the Captain of the wrecked ship for $500, and the Captain then sold it to Gibson for $875. Now Hawaii has two statues. The original stands near the legendary king's birthplace in [[Kapaau|Kapa{{okina}}au]] in [[Kohala, Hawaii|Kohala]], on the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]]. The re-ordered one stands in front of [[Aliiolani Hale|Ali{{okina}}iolani Hale]].<ref>http://www.hisurf.com/explorer/king_kam.htm</ref>
A third replica was commissioned when Hawaii attained statehood and was unveiled in 1969. It stood in the [[United States Capitol]] alongside the [[Father Damien Statue|''Father Damien'' Statue]] and was the heaviest statue in [[Statuary Hall]], weighing 15,000 pounds. In 2008, shortly after Hawaii-born [[Barack Obama]] was nominated as the Democratic Party’s candidate for the presidency, the statue was moved from a dark, back row of Statuary Hall to a prominent position in Emancipation Hall in the Capitol's new visitor center.
The Gould statue can be briefly seen in the opening credits of the original 1960s TV police drama ''[[Hawaii Five-O (1968 TV series)|Hawaii Five-O]]'' as well as the [[Hawaii Five-0 (2010 TV series)|2010 series reboot]]. The statue is also seen multiple times in a three-part series of ''[[Sanford and Son]]'' when the duo go on a vacation to [[Hawaii]]. The statue is seen on a [[pedestal]] outside the Hawaii Police Department Headquarters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.to-hawaii.com/oahu/attractions/kamehamehastatue.php|title=King Kamehameha Statue, Oahu|website=www.to-hawaii.com|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref>
==Big Island== [[Image:Kamehameha statue Wailoa River, Hilo.jpg|thumb |alt=statue with palm trees |The statue in [[Hilo, Hawaii]] ]] Another ''Kamahameha'' statue resides on the [[Hawaii (island)|island of Hawai{{okina}}i]] (known locally as the Big Island). It stands near downtown [[Hilo]] at the north end of the [[Wailoa River State Recreation Area]], where it enjoys a king's view of [[Hilo Bay]]. The {{convert |14 |ft |sing=on}} statue was sculpted by R. Sandrin at the Fracaro Foundry in [[Vicenza]], Italy in 1963 but was not erected on this site and dedicated until June 1997. The statue was originally commissioned for $125,000 by the [[Princeville, Hawaii|Princeville]] Corporation for their resort in [[Kauai]]. However, the people of Kauai did not want the statue erected there, as Kauai was never conquered by King Kamehameha I. Hilo, however, was one of the political centers of King Kamehameha I. Consequently, the Princeville Corporation donated the statue to the Big Island of Hawaii via the Kamehameha Schools Alumni Association, East Hawaii Chapter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://karakullake.blogspot.com/2009/10/5-king-kamehameha-statues.html|title=5 King Kamehameha Statues|date=2009-10-17|website=Tamerlane's Thoughts|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref>
==Kane work== The Grand [[Wailea, Hawaii|Wailea]] Resort Hotel & Spa on [[Maui]] is the home of a fifth ''Kamehameha'' statue. Hawaiian artist, author and historian [[Herb Kawainui Kane]] created the nine-and-a-half-foot work, which presides over the entrance of the hotel, facing the porte cochere. It is purported to be the most lifelike representation of the great warrior king.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.discoveramerica.com/ca/hawaii/big-isl-king-kamehameha-statue.html|title=VisitTheUSA.com Homepage|website=Visit The USA|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref>
==Las Vegas Statue==
There was a sixth statue in Las Vegas, NV, along the Strip at the Hawaiian Marketplace. It was removed in January 2014 to make way for a [[Chili's]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vegas.eater.com/2014/1/21/6294141/king-kamehameha-departs-the-hawaiian-marketplace|title=King Kamehameha Departs the Hawaiian Marketplace|last=Martin|first=Bradley|date=January 21, 2014|work=Eater Vegas|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref>
==Kamehameha Day== Every year on or near the June 11 [[Kamehameha Day]] holiday, ''Kamehameha'' statues are ceremoniously draped in fresh lei fashioned in Hawai{{okina}}i. The event is celebrated in the United States Capitol with traditional [[hula]] performances.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hawaiiforvisitors.com/events/king-kamehameha-day.htm|title=King Kamehameha Day Events in Hawaii|website=www.hawaiiforvisitors.com|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Kamehameha statue Kapaau 1908.jpg|Kapaʻau statue with schoolchildren of plantation workers in 1900s File:Kamehameha Day.jpg|Kapa{{okina}}au statue festooned with [[orchid]] [[Lei (garland)|leis]] on Kamehameha day File:Kamehameha capitol.JPG|The replica in Emancipation Hall in the [[US Capitol Visitor Center]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aoc.gov/art/national-statuary-hall-collection/kamehameha-i|title=Kamehameha I|work=Architect of the Capitol {{!}} United States Capitol|access-date=2018-06-06|language=en}}</ref> File:Kamehameha I head to waist 5111.jpg|Closeup of Honolulu statue </gallery>
==See also== * [[Kamehameha Statue (original cast)|''Kamehameha'' Statue (original cast)]] * [[Kamehameha Statue (Honolulu cast)|''Kamehameha'' Statue (Honolulu cast)]]
== Notes == <references />
==References== *{{cite journal | last = Adler | first = Jacob | title = The Kamehameha Statue | journal = Hawaiian Journal of History | volume = 3 | pages = 87–91 | publisher = Hawaiian Historical Society | location = Honolulu | year = 1969 | hdl = 10125/6299}} *{{cite book | last = Loewen | first = James | title = Lies Across America: What Our Historic Sites Get Wrong | pages = 40–43 | publisher = Touchstone | year = 2007 }} *{{cite book | last = Wharton | first = Glenn | title = The Painted King: Art, Activism, and Authenticity in Hawaii | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | location = Honolulu | year = 2011 }}

The '''Legacy Collection''' is a collection of [[Virtual Studio Technology|VST]] instruments from [[Korg]] and was released in 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vintagesynth.com/korg/legacy.php|title=Korg Legacy Collection {{!}} Vintage Synth Explorer|website=www.vintagesynth.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-03}}</ref> It consists of the [[Korg MS-20]], [[Korg Polysix]], [[Korg Wavestation]], [[ARP Odyssey]] (under the later released Korg collection), [[Korg Mono/Poly]], [[Korg M1]] and Korg MDE-X Multi FX processor. They use Korg's proprietary CMT (Component Modeling Technology) to emulate the original hardware. The Legacy collection is compatible with [[Audio Stream Input/Output|ASIO]] [[Real Time AudioSuite|RTAS]] VST<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.audiotechnology.com.au/wp/index.php/korg-legacy-collection-analog-digital-edition-2007/|title=KORG LEGACY COLLECTION ANALOG & DIGITAL EDITION 2007|website=www.audiotechnology.com.au|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-03}}</ref> and stand alone so it can be used without a [[Digital audio workstation|DAW]]. It is compatible with both the [[Personal computer|PC]] and [[Macintosh|Mac]] and the software was originally supplied on [[CD-ROM]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.soundonsound.com/reviews/korg-legacy-collection-part1|title=Korg Legacy Collection (Part 1) {{!}}|website=www.soundonsound.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-09-03}}</ref> but can now be downloaded via Korg's online store.
==Instruments== ===MS-20=== Replicates the original [[monophonic]] synth but now has 32 voice [[Polyphony and monophony in instruments|polyphony]]. Complete with patch cables. Each knob can be controlled via [[MIDI]].
===Korg Polysix=== The original was only 6-voice polyphonic, but is now up to 32 voices. The [[Low-frequency oscillation|LFO]] and Arpeggiator can be synchronized to MIDI clock.
===Korg Wavestation=== The original had a 32 kHz sample rate and the new plug-in supports 44.1 through 96 kHz and 550 presets.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mixonline.com/recording/korg-legacy-collection-virtual-instrumentseffects-plug-ins-372447|title=Korg Legacy Collection of Virtual Instruments/Effects Plug-Ins|work=Mixonline|access-date=2018-09-03|language=en-us}}</ref>
===Korg Mono/Poly=== Korg have added eight powerful virtual patches for near infinite modulation routing and up to 128 voices.
===Korg M1=== Is 8 part multi-timbral and features up to 256 notes of polyphony.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.emusician.com/gear/korg-legacy-collection-digital-edition|title=KORG LEGACY COLLECTION DIGITAL EDITION|work=EMusician|access-date=2018-09-03|language=en-us}}</ref> Contains all 19 optional ROM cards,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.musicradar.com/reviews/tech/korg-legacy-collection-digital-edition-22053|title=Korg Legacy Collection Digital Edition review|work=MusicRadar|access-date=2018-09-03|language=EN-GB}}</ref> and the full sound set of the T Series.
==Korg Collection== On December 22, 2017 Korg renamed from KORG Legacy Collection series to KORG Collection<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mixdownmag.com.au/korg-updates-legacy-collection-software-synthesisers|title=KORG updates Legacy Collection of software synthesisers|work=Mixdown|access-date=2018-09-03|language=en}}</ref> which now includes:

{{linguistics}} The term "'''linguistic ecology'''" (also known as "'''ecolinguistics'''" or "'''language ecology'''") was first used in an article on the "language situation" in Arizona (Voegelin, Voegelin and Schutz, 1967).
==Description== It was taken up by [[Einar Haugen]], who pioneered a form of [[linguistics]] which used the metaphor of an ecosystem to describe the relationships among the diverse forms of language found in the world, and the groups of people who speak them. Linguistic ecology looks at how languages interact with each other and the places they are spoken in, and frequently argues for the preservation of [[endangered language]]s as an analogy of the preservation of [[biological species]].
Linguistic ecology has often been described as a form of [[ecolinguistics]] (e.g., in Fill and Mühlhäusler). However, some claim that this is more properly considered a form of sociolinguistics, since the focus is on humans and language, rather than the life-sustaining interactions of humans, other species and the physical environment. Steffensen (2007) has argued that separation of the metaphorical 'linguistic ecology' from ecolinguistics would be reductionist, because high [[linguistic diversity]] is associated with high [[biological diversity]] (see Bastardas-Boada 2002). The relationship between linguistic diversity<ref>(Esperanto with English subtitles) Evildea, ''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M5xdm1HcVdE Ĉu Esperanto savos aŭ estingos la aliajn lingvojn ?]'' (Will Esperanto save or extinguish the other languages), YouTube</ref> and biodiversity is claimed to arise since local ecological knowledge is built into local language varieties and threatened if the local language is threatened by a more dominant language (see Mühlhäusler 1995).
Linguistic ecology is represented by the journal ''Language Ecology'' which describes the field as follows:
"The ecology of language is a framework for the study of language as conceptualised primarily in Einar Haugen's 1971/72 work, where he defines language ecology as "the study of interactions between any given language and its environment". It was a reaction to the abstract notion of language – as a monolithic, decontextualised, static entity – propagated by [[Chomsky]], and it was conceived as a broad and interdisciplinary framework. In his use of 'ecology' as a metaphor from biology in linguistics, Haugen formulated ten questions which together comprehensively address factors pertaining to the positioning of languages in their environment. Each of these relates to a traditional sub-field of the study of language – encompassing historical linguistics, linguistic demography, sociolinguistics, contact, variation, philology, planning and policy,<ref>Hult, F.M. (2010). Analysis of language policy discourses across the scales of space and time. ''International Journal of the Sociology of Language, 202'', 7-24.</ref><ref>Hornberger, N.H., & Hult, F.M. (2008). Ecological language education policy. In B. Spolsky & F.M. Hult (Eds.), ''Handbook of educational linguistics'' (pp. 280-296). Malden, MA: Blackwell.</ref> politics of language, [[ethnolinguistics]],<ref>Hult, F.M. (2009). Language ecology and linguistic landscape analysis. In E. Shohamy & D. Gorter (Eds.), ''Linguistic landscape: Expanding the scenery'' (pp. 88-104). London: Routledge.</ref> and typology – and each of them intersects with one or more of the other sub-fields.
==Summary== Taken together, answering some or all of these questions is part of the enterprise of the ecology of language. Since then the notion of ecology in linguistics has evolved to address matters of social, educational,<ref>Hult, F.M. (2012). Ecology and multilingual education. In C. Chapelle (Gen. Ed.), ''Encyclopedia of applied linguistics'' (Vol. 3, pp. 1835-1840). Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell.</ref> historical and developmental nature. With the development of ecology as a special branch of biology, and issues of the 20th and 21st centuries such as migration, hybridity and marginalisation coming to the fore, the notion of language ecology plays an important part in addressing broad issues of language and societal change, endangerment, human rights, as well as more theoretical questions of classification and perceptions of languages, as envisaged in Haugen's work" (''Language Ecology'' 2016).
== See also == * [[Language geography]] * [[Language policy]] * [[Linguistic rights]]

Context, contacts and sociolinguistic dynamics]. Barcelona: Proa. *Bastardas-Boada, Albert (2002) [http://www.teluq.uquebec.ca/diverscite/SecArtic/Arts/2002/bastarda/ftxt.htm "Biological and linguistic diversity: Transdisciplinary explorations for a socioecology of languages"] Diverscité langues, vol. VII. *Bastardas-Boada, Albert (2002) "The Ecological perspective: Benefits and risks for Sociolinguistics and Language Policy and Planning", in: Fill, Alwin, Hermine Penz, & W. Berna: Peter Lang, pp. 77–88. *Bastardas-Boada, Albert (2007) [https://web.archive.org/web/20071201001352/http://bibliotecavirtualut.suagm.edu/Glossa/Journal/jun2007/Linguistic%20Sustainability%20for%20a%20Multilingual%20Humanity.pdf "Linguistic sustainability for a multilingual humanity"] Glossa. Donostia-San Sebastián: Eusko Ikaskuntza. *Steffensen, Sune Vork (2007): "Language, Ecology and Society: An introduction to Dialectical Linguistics." [[Hans Ehrenberg]] }} '''Ludwig Joseph Brentano''' ({{IPAc-en|b|r|ɛ|n|ˈ|t|ɑː|n|oʊ}}; {{IPA-de|bʁɛnˈtaːno|lang}}; 18 December 1844 – 9 September 1931) was an eminent [[Germany|German]] [[economics|economist]] and social reformer. ==Biography== {{unsourced|section|date=August 2017}} Lujo Brentano, born in [[Aschaffenburg]] into a distinguished German Roman Catholic intellectual family (originally of [[Italy|Italian]] [[Cultural heritage|descent]]),Lujo Brentano was the son of the writer [[Christian Brentano]], nephew of writers [[Clemens Brentano]] and [[Bettina von Arnim]], two major figures in the romantic movement in German literature, and the brother of [[Franz Brentano]], a philosopher whose students included [[Edmund Husserl]], [[Alexius Meinong]] and [[Sigmund Freud]], among others. attended [[school]] in [[Augsburg]] and [[Aschaffenburg]]. He studied in [[Dublin]] ([[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]]), [[Münster]], [[Munich]], [[Heidelberg]] (doctorate in law), [[Würzburg]], [[Göttingen]] (doctorate in economics), and Berlin ([[habilitation]] in economics, 1871). He was a professor of [[economics]] and state sciences at the [[university|universities]] of [[Breslau]], [[Strasbourg]], [[Vienna]], [[Leipzig]], and most importantly, Munich (1891–1914). With [[Ernst Engel]], the statistician, he made an investigation of the [[England|English]] [[trade union]]s.{{Cite NIE|wstitle=Brentano, Lujo|year=1905}} In 1914, he signed the [[Manifesto of the Ninety-Three]]. After the [[German Revolution of 1918–1919|revolution of November 1918]], he served in minister-president [[Kurt Eisner]]'s government of the [[People's State of Bavaria]] as People's Commissar (Minister) for Trade, but only for some days in December 1918.{{cn|date=August 2017}} Brentano died in Munich in 1931, aged 86.{{cn|date=August 2017}} ==Legacy== Brentano was a ''[[Kathedersozialist]]'' (reform-minded) and a founding member of the [[Verein für Socialpolitik]]. His influence on the [[social market economy]], and on many Germans who would be leaders just after the end of [[World War II]], can hardly be overrated. He also influenced later economists, such as his doctoral student [[Arthur Salz]]. Note: It is often mistakenly claimed that Brentano was called Ludwig Joseph, and that "Lujo" was a kind of nickname or contraction. This is incorrect; while he was given his name after a [[Ludwig (given name)|Ludwig]] and a [[Joseph (name)|Joseph]], Lujo was his real and legal [[first name]]. (See his autobiography, ''Mein Leben...'', below, p. 18.) ==Bibliography== * Brentano, Lujo (1871–72). ''Die Arbeitergilden der Gegenwart.'' 2 vols., Leipzig: Duncker und Humblot. (English: ''On the History and Development of Gilds and the Origins of Trade Unions.'' 1870.) * Brentano, Lujo (1901). ''Ethik und Volkswirtschaft in der Geschichte. November 1901.'' München: Wolf. * Brentano, Lujo (1910). "The Doctrine of Malthus and the Increase of Population During the Last Decades." ''Economic Journal'' vol. '''20'''(79), pp. 371–93. * Brentano, Lujo (1923). ''Der wirtschaftende Mensch in der Geschichte.'' Leipzig: Meiner. Reprint Marburg: Metropolis, 200ß. * Brentano, Lujo (1924). ''[http://sammlungen.ub.uni-frankfurt.de/freimann/content/titleinfo/177613 Wege zur Verständigung - Der Judenhass].'' Berlin, Philo Verlag und Buchhandlung * Brentano, Lujo (1927–29). ''Eine Geschichte der wirtschaftlichen Entwicklung Englands.'' 4 vols., Jena: Gustav Fischer. * Brentano, Lujo (1929). ''Das Wirtschaftsleben der antiken Welt.'' Jena: Fischer. * Brentano, Lujo (1931). ''Mein Leben im Kampf um die soziale Entwicklung Deutschlands.'' Jena: Diederichs. Reprint Marburg: Metropolis, 2004. * Brentano, Lujo (1924). ''Konkrete Bedingungen der Volkswirtschaft.'' Leipzig: Meiner. 1924. Reprint Marburg: Metropols, 2003. * Brentano, Lujo (1877–1924). ''Der tätige Mensch und die Wissenschaft von der Wirtschaft.'' Reprint Marburg: Metropolis, 2006. * Essays, including "The Industrialist".[[Rudolf Steiner]], ''Education as a Force for Social Change'', Anthroposophic Press, 1997, Lecture 1 (Dornach / August 9, 1919): "I recently mentioned the example of the famous professor Lujo Brentano, a leading modern economist in Middle Europe who recently wrote an article entitled “The Industrialist.” In it he develops three characteristics of an industrialist." ==See also== {{commons category}} {{Wikisource1911Enc|Brentano, Ludwig Joseph|Lujo Brentano}} * [[Liberalism]] * [[Contributions to liberal theory]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{PM20|FID=pe/002455}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brentano, Lujo}} [[Category:1844 births]] [[Category:1931 deaths]] [[Category:People from Aschaffenburg]] [[Category:People from the Kingdom of Bavaria]] [[Category:German economists]] [[Category:German people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich alumni]] [[Category:Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich faculty]] [[Category:German social liberals]] [[Category:University of Münster alumni]] [[Category:Heidelberg University alumni]] [[Category:University of Würzburg alumni]] [[Category:University of Göttingen alumni]] [[Category:Humboldt University of Berlin alumni]] [[Category:University of Strasbourg faculty]] [[Category:University of Breslau faculty]] [[Category:University of Vienna faculty]] [[Category:Leipzig University faculty]] [[Category:Members of the Bavarian Maximilian Order for Science and Art]] [[Category:Social reformers]]

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox Website | name = ''Magazeta'' | logo = | screenshot = Magazeta screenshot.png | caption = Screenshot of the main page | url = [http://magazeta.com magazeta.com] | alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 171,446 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/magazeta.com |title= Magazeta.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> | commercial = No | type = [[Collaborative blog]] | language = [[Russian language|Russian]] | registration = Not required | registered users = | owner = | author = Alexander Maltsev | launch date = October 2005 }} '''''Magazeta''''' ({{lang-ru|Магазета}}) is a popular Russian-language [[Online magazine|web-magazine]] and [[collaborative blog]] on [[China]] and [[Chinese culture]].
==Name and history== Founded in 2005 by Alexander Maltsev (马玉玺, Mǎ Yùxǐ), ''Magazeta'' developed from a [[Livejournal|LJ]] blog. The first publication is dated October 23, 2005.
In October 2006 ''Magazeta'' received two awards in [[The BOBs (weblog award)|The Best of Blogs]] competition.<ref>http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2236051,00.html</ref>
In May 2007, ''Magazeta'' is re-launched at the current address, [http://magazeta.com magazeta.com].
''Magazeta'' was initially authored by a single person, but then was transformed into a collaborative blog with a number of authors.
The name "Magazeta" derives from the word "Ma" (the founder's Chinese surname), plus the Russian word "[[wikt:газета|gazeta]]" (a journal, newspaper).
==Blocking== {{see also|Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China}} ''Magazeta'' experienced several bans by the [[People's Republic of China|PRC]] authorities up to a complete blocking in September 2007. After more than a year, the website was unblocked by the [[Golden Shield Project|Great Firewall]] in November 2008.
==Projects and articles== ''Magazeta'' has started several online projects related to China, such as:
* Online Chinese-Russian dictionary of slang (including [[Internet slang]]) * [http://laowaicast.rpod.ru Laowaicast], a popular [[podcast]] on China-related topics, winner of Podcast Awards 2010 and 2011 in multiple categories, finalist of [[The BOBs]] in 2010. * ChinaFilm, a collaborative translation project for Chinese movies<ref>http://chinafilm.tv</ref>
===Topics=== Recurrent topics for articles in ''Magazeta'' include:
* [[Chinese character]] of the day * China-related news * [[Chinese culture]] * [[Chinese films]] * [[Chinese language]] * Photos of China * [[Chinese music]] * Interviews * [[Podcast]]s
==See also== *[[Internet in the People's Republic of China]]
